characters: JUNEBUG AND DOT, ORCHID, THE X-FORCE WATCHING THIS SPECTA
WE HEAR THE POUNDING OF THE FEET STOMPING AND THE HANDS
WE SEE DELACROIX, SLOAN, CHEEBA WITH LOURDESE, DUNWITTY,
OFF-SCREEN, WE HEAR A RUCKUS, A BIG COMMOTION. VOICES
A THUNDEROUS ROAR FROM THE STUDIO AUDIENCE.
ON SLOAN, JESSICA, MANTAN, AND CHEEBA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WE are in the living quarters of PIERRE DELACROIX.  The windows overlook the Brooklyn Promenade and the majestic lower Manhattan skyline.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bonjour, my name is Pierre Delacroix. I'm a television writer, also a showrunner, a creative person.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see a tall figure move in and around the space.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm one of those people responsible for what you view on your idiot box.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Monogrammed cuff sleeve - the initials P.D.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The problem is not enough of you have been watching.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Monogrammed shirt pocket - the initials P.D.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With the onslaught of the internet, video and interactive games, nine hundred channels to choose from and whatnot, our valued audience has dramatically eroded.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Razor cuts a path through a white foam on a black face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To put it in much more simple terms...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Delacroix YELLS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like rats fleeing a sinking ship.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The handsome face of Pierre Delacroix.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: People tuning out by the millions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Delacroix turns to the CAMERA and addresses US.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which is not good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The tenement building is boarded up, condemned, bombed ou but a home, a shelter nonetheless.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: People to our surprise live in here.  It is a commune.  T homeless, people who have been left out, forgot about, written off, and don't matter.  The fringes of society. CHEEBA, a skinny Puerto Rican male, tries to wake a slumbering body under a mass of old newspapers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yo, let's get to it.  You don't dance, we don't eat.  Simple as that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The mass begins to move.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right.  We slow.  We blow. We snooze.  We lose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MANRAY, a young African-American dread-lock male, and Che are getting set up in front of the entrance to the CONTINENTAL NETWORK SYSTEM building.  CNS is one of the fledgling, upstart new networks, trying to battle with AB NBC, CBS, FOX, WB, and UPN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Entrance.  Cheeba is putting the portable floor down on t sidewalk.  Manray sits on the curb, taking the sneakers o and putting on his tap shoes; bottle caps are on the sole of the shoes instead of real taps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good morning, ladies and gentlemen. I know everybody is in a hurry to work, ready to begin another day in this rat race.  But don't sleep us. I'm Cheeba and I introduce to you the world renown MANRAY, the man with the educated feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Manray takes a small bow.  A few, not many, people have stopped to look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As we continue our world wind tour, we would like to give you a little somethin', somethin' before you go off to make that money.  I give you Manray.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Manray, who starts to do his thing, and when he starts do his thing attention must be paid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crowd, as Manray gets busy, people gather to watch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Delacroix, he is about to walk into the CNS building but stops to check out Manray.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Manray, he pounds out some intricate steps and freezes at the end of the move.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crowd, who applaud as Cheeba unfolds a brown shopping bag and holds it out in front of them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you very much but please don't go without giving us some cheddar, cheese, money.  We prefer two's than fews.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: People are digging into their pockets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I would like to add that both of us are homeless.  Not that it means anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A WOMAN is about to dump some change in the brown paper b

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I said homeless.  Ladies and gentlemen.  Senorita, do you know what that means?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cheeba looks at her and she quickly pulls out a 5-spot fr her purse and drops it into the bag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Muchos gracias.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cheeba works his way over to Delacroix.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good morning, Cheeba.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good morning to you, Mr. Delapot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: De-la-croix.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Y'know what I mean.  Got a gig yet for Manray and I yet?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Delacroix hands Cheeba a ten dollar bill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gracias.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Delacroix moves towards the revolving doors of CNS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Manray, Sloan says you're too talented to be dancing on the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well do something about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Delacroix is the lone person of color in the elevator.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Delacroix gets off the elevator, takes out his ID, slips through the scanner and enters the reception area of CNS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good morning, Marie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not gonna be a good morning for you if you don't get into Dunwitty's staff meeting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What staff meeting?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The staff meeting that started 30 minutes ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Delacroix walks, or better yet, slithers into the staff meeting that is already in progress.  TWENTY WRITERS sit around an oval table, all are Caucasian except Delacroix, again he's the lone person of color, the "fly in the buttermilk." DUNWITTY, Senior V.P. of the Entertainment Division of CN looks at Delacroix and waits for him to sit down before h continues.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Monsieur Delacroix, this very important meeting commenced...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dunwitty looks at his Rolex Chronograph - Daytona Model.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...exactly thirty-two minutes ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry I'm late.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you know how much information can be dispensed in one minute alone?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't find out about this very important staff meeting until...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Delacroix looks at his Jaeger-LeCoultre.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Four minutes ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So are you telling me everyone knew about this get-together except you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wasn't told about this until Marie informed me as soon as I got off the elevator.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All eyes are on Delacroix and he feels it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: People, you can attempt to pull a Rodman like our friend Delacroix, but I guarantee you'll be sent packing just like him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dunwitty via remote turns off the lights and turns on an overhead projector.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These are the standings.  Read 'em and weep.  As you can plainly see the Continental Network System is languishing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ratings charts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at 'em people.  We are BOOTY, CA CA.  We are DOO-DOO.  Doo-doo on a stick, if you will.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dunwitty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do not like to be the laughing stock of the broadcast industry.  I have pride and people, you better start getting some too.  These numbers have to go up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dunwitty turns on the lights.  JOAN, one of the writers, raises her hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Question?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what do you want us to do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What I want everyone to do is write some material that is FUNNY.  The junk you've been writing is about as funny as a dead baby.  It's not funny, it's not new.  It's not sexy. It, it, it...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sucks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Conference room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SUCKS.  Thank you, Fish.  This meeting is over but I want everyone to seriously think about what I said and how you can deliver.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: People scurry out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Monsieur Delacroix, in my office now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The writers, beat down, come out of the conference room a move past SLOAN HOPKINS, a highly attractive African- American "sistuh." Delacroix sees Sloan and holds her arm as they walk.  He talks under his breath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How was it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why didn't you tell me about this staff meeting?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody told me anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What good are you if you don't tell me stuff like this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It wasn't my fault.  If I would have known, I would have known.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Delacroix enters his corner office, which has huge action photos of ALI, JORDAN, GRIFFEY, TYSON, AARON and JABBAR o his walls, it is also decorated with African art througho

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Office.  Dunwitty looks at the floor-to-ceiling windows overlooking mid-town Manhattan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you know what C.P. Time is?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C.P. Time is Colored People's Time. The stereotypical belief that Negroes are always late.  That Negroes have no sense of time - time except when it comes to music or dance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They both laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's sit down over there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dunwitty and Delacroix sit on the sofa.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry about my blowup but I have to have a whipping boy every meeting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I understand.  But again, in all honesty I was not informed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forget it.  I believe you're my most creative person I've got on staff.  You're hip.  You know what's happening.  I got some corny white boys and girls writing for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Delacroix doesn't join him in his laughter because he doesn't know how to take that comment or where Dunwitty i headed with it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I understand Black culture.  I grew up around black people all my life. If the truth be told I probably know "niggers" better than you, Monsieur Delacroix.  Please don't get offended by my use of the quote-unquote N word.  I got a black wife and three bi-racial children, so I feel I have a right to use that word.  I don't give a damn what Spike says, Tarantino is right.  Nigger is just a word.  If Dirty Ole Bastard can use it every other word so can I.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I would prefer you not use that word in my presence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NIGGER.  NIGGER.  NIGGER.  NIGGER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Delacroix pounces on top of Dunwitty like a cat on a mous and gives him a quick BROOKLYN BEAT DOWN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say it again.  C'mon, say it again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dunwitty.  He's a bloody pulp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Delacroix. He straightens his tie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's a nigger now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: POW.  This is a fantasy in Delacroix's mind.  We go BACK REALITY.  Everything's how we left it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The material you've been creating is too white bread.  White people with black faces.  The Huxtable's, Cosby, revolutionary.  But that's dead.  We can't go down that road again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't agree.  The Negro middle class does exist, and it's rich material for a dramatic series or sitcom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm telling you it's not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He goes to his desk, picks up Delacroix's scripts and sta throwing them one by one against the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The middle class black family moves into a white suburban enclave.  The middle class black family moves into a small Southern town that is run by the KKK.  The middle class single black father raises his teenage daughter.  The middle class single black father raises his teenage daughter.  The middle class single black mother raises her teenage son.  And so on and so forth.  It's too clean, too antiseptic...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...to white?  I still feel all of my scripts would make good shows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Delacroix, wake up, brother man. The reason why they didn't get picked up was because nobody - and I mean NOBODY - niggers and crackers alike wants to see that junk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've never been given a fair shot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got your head stuck up your ass with your Harvard education and your pretentious ways.  Brother man, I'm blacker than you.  I'm keepin' it real and you're frontin', trying to be white.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm an oreo, a sell out?  Because I don't aspire to do HOMEBOYS FROM OUT OF SPACE, SECRET DIARY OF DESMOND PFEIFFER, A PJ's or some as you might put it, some "nigger" show?  I'm a Tom?  I'm whiter than white and you're blacker than black? Is that what you think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's exactly what I think.  I want you to create something that people want to see.  Let's be honest, the majority of the people in the country are deaf, dumb and blind and I'm including 35 million African-Americans.  You know and I know "niggers" set the trend, set the styles.  This is a golden opportunity now.  These idiots have to be led to the water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not sure if I can deliver what you want.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You will or you'll be back at BET so quick you'll never know what hit you.  I need a mid-season replacement and pronto.  It will be on the fast track.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it you want from me?  Some plantation follies?  Some sitcom that takes place on a watermelon patch?  Some show that follows four nigger generations of junkies and crackheads?  You want me to go back to the ante bellum days?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes!  Yes!  Yes!  I want a show that will make headlines, that will have millions and millions of households tuned in, glued to their televisions every week.  I want advertisers dying to buy on this show.  I'm gonna squeeze this show out of you if it kills you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WE SEE a street lamp, and coming out of it are some wires WE FOLLOW the wires into a tenement building. The residents have tapped into a street light courtesy of CON EDISON for power.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cheeba stands in front of the makeshift kitchen, which includes a hot plate, and prepares a gourmet meal of a ta Spanish dish.  The clean apartment is furnished with stuf people have thrown out that they picked up on the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm starvin' like Marvin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My world famous, famous world Arroz con pollo will be ready very soon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hurry up, I wanna watch HBO.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did we get our bill yet?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They both laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess that will come with the rent, gas, and Con Ed bills, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ahh, the luxuries of life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yo, check it.  This is good and all that but one day soon I want to have much Benjamins so I can have a nice crib and pay all my bills. You hear me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chill, I'm the brains behind this outfit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I'm the feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yo, you gotta show some patience. You want me to snap my fingers and presto chango - you're an overnight sensation.  Son, there is no such thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm tired of waiting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sits in front of a large flat-screen television, watch the Yankee game and eating his takeout Chinese food.  On of the monitor, he has attached a sign that reads "FEED T

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She sits in front of her television, hand on remote, flip channels and eating takeout Chinese food.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They both are devouring the chicken with rice, as they wa bootleg HBO.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Delacroix sits at his desk, a ream of white bond paper in front of him, a box of number-two pencils and an electric pencil sharpener.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was never good at performing under the gun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pencil after pencil gets inserted and sharpened to a knif like point.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, this wasn't a gun, it was a bazooka and it was pressed dead blank right against my dome.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Delacroix, staring at the blank ream of paper.  It is ver intimidating.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Monitor.  Bernie Williams is at the plate for the New Yor Yankees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sign atop monitor.  Again, it reads "FEED THE IDIOT BOX."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She too is blank.  A screen saver bobs and weaves on her laptop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Delacroix grabs a pencil and put it to paper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paper.  He doodles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Manray screws out the bare light bulb which is the sole source of illumination and lays down onto his mattress on the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sloan closes her laptop and jumps into her bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Delacroix is already in the bed, the lights are out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Delacroix, who's wide awake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Manray and Cheeba are both sound asleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cheeba, he has a sheet pulled over his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Manray, who's sawing logs, snoring loudly.

dialogues.speaker: OFF-SCREEN, WE HEAR A RUCKUS, A BIG COMMOTION. VOICES
dialogues.text: yelling.  Police sirens, cars and trucks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Apartment.  Cheeba and Manray run to the window and look

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The street is filled with police cars, vans and wagons. Helicopters hover overhead with their searchlights on the building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh snap!  It's a raid!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cheeba and Manray jump into their cloths.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cops in riot gear storm into the tenement.  A police chie barks over a speaker system.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please evacuate this building.  All of you are illegal residents of this condemned building.  Please leave immediately, by order of the Mayor of New York City, Rudolph Giuliani.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stairwell.  It's bedlam.  The hundreds of SQUATTERS who h been living here all making a bad dash trying to flee the NYPD as they "bumrush the show."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Floor.  Cheeba and Manray try to push against the crowd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not this way.  Out through the fire escape.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The COPS are running up the staircase.  People try to esc with as many of their belongings that they can hold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My tap shoes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EUREKA!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He jumps out of bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh my God!!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She too jumps out of bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is a MADHOUSE, BEDLAM.  It's PANDEMONIUM.  The Squatte are being seized as soon as they come out of the tenement Searchlights go back and forth, as the cops make their arrests and fill the "Paddy" wagons.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Street.  The Squatters are like ROACHES in a dark kitchen night, scrambling as the lights turn on.  Do you remember those old "RAID" commercials.  "Let's scram, IT'S RAID!!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The phone rings.

dialogues.speaker: CU OF DELACROIX AND SLOAN
dialogues.text: Delacroix picks it up.  They yell in unison.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Manray!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Manray!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How did you know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It hit me like a ton of bricks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How can this be?  You and me at the same time, the exact same thought. It's scary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The idea was out there in the universe.  Now what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cheeba and Manray run down the fire escape and just elude group of cops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fence.  They lay still as the Fuzz run past them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We ran out without my shoes and the floor.  I gotta get my stuff.  What about our savings?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you crazy?  The joint is crawling with cops now.  You wanna go to Rikers?  Go to the hoosegow?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Manray looks at his friend, he knows he is right, at leas this time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Delacroix and Sloan sip hot coffee as they stand in front their office building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Manray was under our nose the whole time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you know how you will use him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not yet, but this thing will never get made.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You lost me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dunwitty wants a Coon show.  And that's what I'm going to give him, it's going to be so racist, so negative, he won't have the balls to put it on the air.  Hence I'll prove my point.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What point is that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The point being that him, the networks don't want Black people on television unless they are buffoons.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sounds risky to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You getting cold feet?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm in till the end.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good.  I'm going to need your support.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't you just quit?  Walk away?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And lose out on my money?  The only way I get paid is if I get fired. And that's what I intend to do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is pouring rain and Delacroix and Sloan huddle under a umbrella.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everything was going according to plan.  I was working on the outline. Dunwitty was off my back for now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Delacroix.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But there was a catch.  A big catch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sloan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Manray and Cheeba were nowhere to be found.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Manray and Cheeba are soaking wet.  They stand together i doorway, trying to stay out of the elements.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Street.  They run in the downpour.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was like they had disappeared off the face of the earth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cheeba.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I had no contact numbers, no address, no beeper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Manray.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No nuthin', no clues...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is a sunny and pleasant morning.  Again, Sloan and Delacroix hold vigil.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe something happened to them. Maybe they're lying in an alley bleed to death.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Manray better not be bleeding to death.  I need him.  After we're done he can do whatever he wants to do, until then, he's ours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're beginning to sound like Dunwitty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Manray and Cheeba stand across the street from their form residence.  All of the doors and windows have been boarde up and two cops stand watch.  They both look defeated, di and hungry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sloan gets off the elevator and sees a skirmish.  TWO SECURITY GUARDS are trying to escort Manray and Cheeba ou of the building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His name is Delapoint.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WE have no one by that name.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Delapot.  Dela-something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: De La Soul ain't here either. Let's go.  Out.  Off the premises.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Manray turns around and sees Sloan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sloan!  She knows us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The security guard stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's alright.  They are associates of Mr. Delacroix.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry, Ms. Hopkins.  They both walked in off the street without an appointment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you need an escort?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That won't be needed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sits in front of his TV and watches a tape of the old "Amos 'n' Andy" show.  Sloan leads Manray and Cheeba in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eureka!  Where've you been?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hugs them both.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sloan and I have been looking all over for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'd take no offense if we called you DeLa for short?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No offense.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Manray needs a job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Delacroix smiles at Sloan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We got evicted from our home. We've both been on the streets for the last week.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We was coming to see you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If it's not too much trouble could you order us some food?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're starving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I apologize.  What would you like to eat?  Anything you want.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A feast of McDonald's is taking place.  Cheeba and Manray are stuffing Big Macs, Fish Deluxes and large french frie into their mouths.  They were famished.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have this concept for a TV pilot. There's no guarantee it will get made but regardless, you'll still make some money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How much?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: First things first.  I have to know if Manray is up for this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do I have to do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some tap dancing, some singing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where do I sign?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What kind of show is this gonna be?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Different.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How different?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trust me.  Of course I still have to pitch it to my boss, but we'll have an answer one way or the other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DeLa, I'm aboard.  As long as I get to hoof and get paid too!!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right.  Money turns the wheel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about in the mean time?  Not the in between time?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll both get an advance and you can stay with me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I would like to change your name.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're now Mantan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mantan?  I don't even care as long as I'm dancing.  Which reminds me, I need some new kicks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Manray holds two Capezio shopping bags of shoes as he wal next to Sloan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never had a really real pair before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've never had any formal training, either?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not a class, not a thing, just picked stuff up by myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wish I had your natural talent. God only makes that visit once in a while.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You sing and dance?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A little.  I just graduated from NYU film school.  Cinema studies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what's up with you and DeLa?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you and him kicking it? Knocking boots. Y'knowwhatI'mtalkin'bout.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, we're not knocking boots.  I got this internship while I still was at NYU, DeLa was impressed with my get up and go and hired me to be his assistant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sure that was the only thing he was impressed with.  You look beautiful like that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If that was suppose to be a compliment, I thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're welcome.  You shouldn't give up on performing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why do you say that?  You've never seen me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think that would probably make you the happiest.  When I'm hoofing, I mean really doing my thing, hitting it, nothing compares to that feeling in the world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I envy you.  That's the way I want to feel about my work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sloan walks from the subway to her block.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Street.  A huge black Chevy Suburban follows her, all the windows are tinted jet black, you cannot see it all into She notices the vehicle and starts to walk faster.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Corner.  As Sloan tries to cross at the corner, the Subur pulls up in front of her, blocking her path.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suburban.  A tall black man jumps out of the Chevy.  This BIG BLACK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Li'l Sister.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Corner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You idiot.  You almost gave me a massive coronary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't mean to scare you like that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well you did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give me some?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not huggin' you in the middle of the street.  You must be crazy, Julius.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whoa, hold up li'l sis'.  I done told you 'bout that.  Julius ain't my name, you better recognize Hopkins was our slave name.  My true name is...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not callin you Big Black Africa. Mommy and Daddy named you Julius.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BIG BLACK is the first name and AFRICA is the last.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hugs her, she becomes lost in his huge arms and laughs

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Big Black is rummaging through his sister's refrigerator.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damn, Sis, you don't keep no food up in here in dis' piece.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I order out mostly.  So what do I owe this visit to?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My group we need some exposure. Was wondering if you could hook a brother up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hook you up?  The Mau-Mau's?  You must be smoking.  Why in the world would I want to hook up a bunch of red, black and green flag-waving pseudo revolutionairies?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So now I see where you're coming from.  Just because we ain't rapping about Gucci, Timberland, Rolex, Benz, Cristal, ho's and bitches, we're pseudo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who are you revolting against?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're revolting against the powers that be, that been enslaving the minds and hearts of all people of color.  And we won't stop rapping till we bring about the overthrow of the government of the U.S. of A.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you were really down you would get us together with that boss of yours.  What's his name again?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Delacroix.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What makes you think he would write a show about the Mau-Mau's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C'mon, why not?  The Monkees had a show.  Look at all that other junk that's on TV.  We got underground cult following.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't have the demographics.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So are you telling me that you wouldn't even introduce me to Delacroix or set up a meeting?  I'm talking 'bout me, your only brother, ya own flesh and blood, hook a brother up, youknowwhatI'msayin'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That'swhatI'msayin'.  I'm not blowin' my young career, brother or no brother, for you or anybody else.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a name, a term for your kind, the likes of you.  Back in slavery days, you would be classified as a house nigga.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you think I'm a house nigga then that's your prerogative.  You got your ways to affect change, I have mine.  And I would appreciate it very much if you took ya field nigga ass out of my house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My own sister throwin' me out.  I hope to seeya later when you get ya mind right.  Don't bother letting me out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's mighty black of you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Big Black slams the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One by one, the team enters the office and sits down on t sofa.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Delacroix, I'm glad you got your mind right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's right and tight.  Good morning, let me introduce you to everybody. You know my assistant, Sloan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is Cheeba.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice to meet you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And this is Manray.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good.  I like the names.  Very theatrical.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're all happy to be here and I'm going to paint a picture for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm wid it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've done a lot of soul searching and once again you are right.  In my previous work it's been all surface, superficial.  I have never really dug deep.  Not anymore.  As Mark Twain fully understood satire is the way.  Race has always been a hot button in this country's history and it needs to be pushed harder.  If we are ever to live side by side in peace and harmony. It's about promoting racial healing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go on.  Good so far.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know you're familiar with minstrel shows.  They came about at the turn of the 19th century.  It was a variety show in which the talent was in blackface - singing, dancing, telling jokes, doing skits. Dunwitty, I ask you when was the last time there was a good variety show on the air.  Carol Burnett? HeeHaw?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Word!!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So let's take this great form, this very American tradition of entertainment into the 21st century, into the new millennium.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The name of the show?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is called: MANTAN - THE NEW MILLENNIUM MINSTREL SHOW.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm lovin' it.  You know how I know? Because I'm getting a boner, my Johnson is hard, no disrespect my sister.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dunwitty starts walking around his office, pumping his fi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm feelin' dis'!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It will take a lot of courage and backbone on the part of the CNS to get this on the air.  In fact, I would understand fully if the subject matter is deemed too risque, too controversial.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry about that, that's my department.  Now who do we cast? We need a star.  Can Whoopi sing or dance?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know if Whoopi is the way to go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are these our two stars, sitting here in front of my nose?  Which one is Mantan again?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And Cheeba is Sleep 'n' Eat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cheeba.  A look of surprise is on his face.  Complete, ut surprise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a great handle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mantan and Sleep 'n Eat.  Two real coons.  I know we're way out there but it's satire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want you take it there.  All the way to the edge and back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sloan looks at Delacroix with concern.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Every week we follow the trials and tribulations of two real coons - Mantan and Sleep 'n Eat.  The Dusky Duo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are there character traits?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ignorant, dullwitted, lazy, and unlucky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exactly!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mantan is an uneducated Negro who always by some stroke of unbelievable stupidity makes his best laid plans go haywire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And Sleep 'n Eat is his comical sidekick?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yep, you guessed it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This could be bigger than "Amos and Andy."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Protest finally forced "Amos and Andy" off the air.  Could stop us from ever getting on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let'em try.  I will kill to make this happen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Delacroix looks at Sloan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Negroes would be in an uproar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what.  We would just give the NAACP a donation that would be the end of that.  No such thing as bad publicity.  So what.  Earlier you said singing and dancing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mantan right here is a gifted hoofer.  He has educated feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who are the other characters?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do we have characters?  How about Honeycutt, Snowflake, Rastus, Nigger, Jim, Sambo, Jungle Bunny, and how could we forget Aunt Jemima.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dunwitty is dying with laughter.  He's the only one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We gonna hit 'em wid da BOMB DICKEY on dis' one.  What's the setting?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the projects.  Like Eddie Murphy's "The PJ's."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ya first bad move.  Projects been done.  That's one of the problems now, everything, movies, TV, are set in the urban jungle, da hood. That's so tired.  Mantan's Millennium Minstrel Show should be set on a plantation.  In Alabama.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And every week these Alabama porch monkeys will make us cry, make us laugh, make us look at our own humanity.  Make us feel good to be alive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know about that plantation angle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you talkin' 'bout?  It's the move.  Stay wid me now.  We're movin' fast.  What does everybody else think about this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'd get a lot of mail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She laughs, it's a fake one at that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Dunwitty, there wouldn't be another show like it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've always wanted to be on television.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I like you.  Sleep 'n Eat.  That's funny.  Mantan, how do you feel about performing in black face?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As long as the hoofing is real, that I can do my thing, I can blacken up.  Let me hit it, beats and rhythms, express myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Show me a little somethin' somethin'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mantan starts to put on his new tap shoes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Delacroix, you dug deep, deeper than deep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mantan is ready.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm gonna give you just a taste. My tap shoes are brand new.  I haven't trained 'em yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He starts to work out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rhythms, rhythms, rhythms.  Beats, beats, beats.  No Fred Astaire here, baby.  Just rawness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dunwitty clears his desk of everything, just knocks stuff flying onto the floor.  And Mantan taking the cue, jumps on his desk and really starts hitting it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Delacroix, as he watches his creation, it's not a happy f

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mantan, he's bringing it home.  With the final move, he leaps off the desk into the middle of the office, and FRE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That'swhatI'mtalkin''bout. That'swhatI'mtalkin''bout!  He's off the hiz-hook!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We think so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sleep 'n Eat, what do you do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I play the straight man.  I do some singing and dancing also.  I also manage Mantan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh you do so?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm the man behind the man behind the man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You da man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, you da man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm gonna run upstairs with this. If CNS doesn't want to do this, somebody else will have da balls to pull the trigger.  I want to thank each and every one of you.  This is great, Delacroix.  I'll get back to you later today.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cheeba and Mantan are walking in midtown Manhattan.  They both have a pep in their step, money in their pockets, an roof over their heads.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Life is beginning to look up.  It's all good in da neighborhood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You might be right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why are you smiling so?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His smile is a mile wide.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not smiling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Naw, not you.  It can't be.  That hottie Sloan Hopkins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's that bad, huh?  It's all over my face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No shame in ya game.  She got ya nostrils, ya chnoz is wide open. Sloan's what we certified ladies' men call low hanging fruit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Certified ladies' man, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's also moorish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Moorish.  Ya get a little taste of dat booty, ya wanna get some MORE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seconds and thirds, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sloan is all 'dat.  I try her.  I'm a tri-sexual.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'd try anything.  I got first dibs.  You get ya own stuff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Naw, just jokin'.  That's you. That's you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Delacroix sits with Manray and Cheeba in the living room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want you to start using the name Mantan and not Manray if you don't mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have to start getting into your character.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the risk of sounding ignorant...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cheeba turns quickly towards Manray.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...don't say a word but who is this cat Mantan you keep talkin' 'bout?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Delacroix hits the remote button.  The TV and VCR are pow

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Television.  We see MANTAN MORELAND in some obscure movie

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is Mantan Moreland.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Television.  Mantan reacts to seeing a ghost.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was a clown, a buffoon but he was funny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Living room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That ain't funny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DeLa, I don't know 'bout this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gentlemen, the show, our show will be satirical.  You know what that is, don't you?  Trust me on this one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We might need some mo' money behind this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That can be done.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mantan?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mantan!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE MAU-MAU's in full effect, bob their heads to the funk track that blasts from the studio monitors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Studio.  They pass around joints that look like they've b on steroids and 64 ounce JUGULARS of DA BOMB MALT LIQUOR liquid crack, the preferred alcoholic beverage of GHETTO NEGROES.  All the members of the MAU-MAU's are AFRICAN AMERICAN except one.  There is one Caucasian member.  He goes by the name 1/16th BLACK, the engineer tech-whiz kid computer geek.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yo, Big Black, we needs a name for this joint.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How 'bout...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Big Black takes a long, long drag on a joint, then he quickly empties a 64 oz. in one swing without missing a beat, without missing a head nod.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Black Iz Black?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The whole group goes crazy with the title of the song.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's da bomb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's gonna give me some inspiration.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gonna make me get my flow on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We should call dis da BLACK album.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone starts high-fiving each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yo, check it out.  We have never conformed to none of the white man's rules and regulations and later for that ole slave owner Webster.  Therefore I respectfully submit BIG BLACK that we from now on, hence forth and whatnot spell BLACK: B-L-A-K, not B-L-A-C-K.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I feel dat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: B-L-A-K.  BLAK.  The darkest of all colors, the opposite of white.  A member of an African people.  But check it out, here's where the grey people try to get slick with their trickery.  Listen to the full connotations.  GLOOMY.  DEPRESSING. EVIL.  WICKED.  ANGRY.  SULLEN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BLAK OUT.  BLAK LISTED.  BLAK BALL. Need I say more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: B-L-A-K it is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A middle-aged African-American woman is working in the kitchen.  Delacroix sits at the kitchen table talking wit her.  This is his MOM, ORCHID DOTHAN. Orchid puts a plate of food in front of her son.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You must think I'm some kind of fool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It looks delicious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You hear me talkin' to you.  The only time you come up here when something is wrong.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C'mon, Mommy, don't start with that I'm an ungrateful son stuff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I said no such thing.  All I said is that something must be wrong.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She sits down with him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's the food?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't beat it with a hammer.  Well, since you asked, it looks like I may have a new show, a pilot being shot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's wonderful.  Isn't that what you always wanted, a show of your own?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He talks between mouthfuls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was.  It is.  But this is a different kind of show.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If at first it's not what you want, just work that much harder, Peerless.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mommy, please don't call me that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Son, Peerless is your name.  Now you might be one of these Hollywood types, change your name and all that but Peerless Dothan is on your birth certificate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know what's on my birth certificate.  You heard from Daddy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess he's still on the road. What kind of show is this?  Are they some Negroes in it without being buffoons?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To answer your question, there are a lot of Negroes in it and what is your definition of buffoons?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peerless, I didn't raise a buffoon. We have enough of those on television already.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please let me know when you hear from Daddy, get a number or something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will.  And good luck with your show.  I hope it's a huge success. You've worked very hard.  You deserve it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Delacroix gets up from his seat and hugs his mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A celebration is going on as Delacroix, Sloan, Cheeba and Mantan sit at a table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Table.  Cheeba and Mantan are giddy.  Sloan looks at Delacroix who is visibly not happy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I feel like somebody hit me upside da head with a sledgehammer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DeLa - what's the matter with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ain't happy about the green light?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: People show their happiness in a lot of different ways.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, homeboy, looks like he's at a funeral.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm happy for all of us.  It's just we have a great responsibility now. The pressure is on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pressure?  DeLa, you don't know what the hell real pressure is. SHEEETT!!!  This is lightstuff. Now when you scramblin' out on the street in da January winter and the hawk is talkin' to you with NO money and NO prospects of money anytime soon, now that there is some pressure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't mean it to sound like that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the way it came out.  Let me ask you one question.  Have you ever been in want, in need your entire privileged life?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now I'm privileged?!  Why?  Because I didn't grow up on food stamps and welfare?  Because I didn't call home a cardboard box?  No, I never ever went to bed hungry and I'm proud of it, too.  Whoever told you that living in poverty earns you somekind of badge of honor flat out lied to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The point I'm trying to make is that this is a blessing.  It's going to be fun doing this show and we should all look at it that way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Delacroix gets up from the table and leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's wrong with him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Must be the pressure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cheeba and Mantan laugh, give each other some dap.  A hig attractive PUERTO RICAN female walks over to their table. This is JESSICA GRILLO.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry I'm late.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cheeba and Mantan are in awe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, girl.  This is my best friend, Jessica Grillo.  I invited her down to celebrate with us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm Cheeba.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm Mantan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They both rise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please, have a seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sloan never told us she had friends like you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In fact, we never knew she had any friends period.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Later for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She has a lot of friends

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Male?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A lot?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Enough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sloan and Jessica laugh at the expense of these guys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I propose a toast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She grabs an empty glass and pours herself some champagne

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To the success of your show.  Good luck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone raises their glasses.  CLINK!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sloan gets up from the table and takes after Delacroix.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steps. Sloan catches up with Delacroix at the rest room a

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She goes to the ladies' cubicle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Delacroix.  He leans against the wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bathroom door.  Sloan comes out, grabs him inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sloan locks the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is your problem?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My problem is MANTAN THE NEW MILLENIUM MINSTREL SHOW.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why did you even come up with that shit if you didn't want it made?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was the principle.  Dunwitty had to be enlightened.  I was making a point.  I take pride in my work. Plus, I already told you I wasn't gonna walk away from my money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck da money.  Why do through all this effort?  Why?  Are you looking for love from Dunwitty?  For respect?  Dunwitty and his likes don't give a goddamn about you.  So now what are you gonna do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Someone begins to pound on the bathroom door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you please let me in?  I have to use the toilet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're gonna have to hold it in because we're not finished yet...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She returns her attention to Delacroix.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...QUIT then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Even if money wasn't an issue, Dunwitty will still go ahead without me and that could be more dangerous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the chances of MANTAN being picked up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wouldn't bet against it.  My Negroidal ass is stuck between the proverbial rock and a hard place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like I said, all this for some twisted, distorted sense of principal.  Dunwitty, he just tolerates your Negroidal ass, he doesn't respect it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The banging starts again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please open this bathroom door immediately.  You are being very inconsiderate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sloan unlocks the door and they exit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ladies' bathroom.  Sloan and Delacroix file past the stra looks of the manager and FIVE WOMEN waiting to use the bathroom as they rush in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I strongly feel that a Negro should direct this.  This kind of satire is a high wire act in a gale storm. One misstep and we're doing "Amos and Andy."  Only a Negro will have the sensitivity and cultural awareness to navigate this dangerous terrain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To hire someone solely on their ethnicity, gender or religion is not right.  It's un-American.  I will hire someone who is most qualified for this particular job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was hoping to perhaps direct some episodes myself, if not the pilot soon after.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want a hot, young white director. Maybe the kid, that pheenom who just did that hot new sexy Madonna video.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're telling me some white boy is gonna direct this pilot?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just want you to meet him.  Keep an open mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Besides, what does he know about Negroes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Probably nuthin', but that's why it's such a sexy way to go. Sometimes an outsider has a fresh new outlook, a different unique perspective.  A black director, y'know what he's gonna do given the subject matter?  With this kid, the possibilities are endless.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are his qualifications besides being a white male and directing a hot new sexy freaky Madonna video?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If Spielburg can direct "The Color Purple" and "Amistad", our whiz kid can direct the Mantan pilot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's exactly my point.  Has he even directed actors before in anything?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No!!!  Just meet the guy.  That's all I'm asking.  Look, I'll even let you choose your own musical director.  You can have that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the immortal words of Derrick Coleman, WHOOOPDEEDAMNDOO!!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Derrick Coleman, he possessed all the talent in the world, coulda, shoulda, been a great ballplayer but alas D.C. didn't want it bad enough.  Delacroix, do you want it? Bad enough to kill for it?  Do you want it that much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Delacroix stares at Dunwitty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Delacroix, followed by Sloan, enters the room full of wri

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Delacroix He surveys the room.

dialogues.speaker: DELACROIX
dialogues.text: All of the writers are Caucasian - male and female.  Ever single last one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Conference room.  Delacroix and Sloan sit down at the hea of the long oval table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good morning, for those of you who don't know me, I'm Pierre Delacroix. I'm running things and this here is my assistant Sloan Hopkins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've never worked with any of you and you've never worked with me so we'll be starting from scratch. I'm a fair person, a straight shooter and I don't hold my tongue. Everybody up in here should know I had nothing to do with you being hired.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I would have preferred at least one other Negro writer.  Any questions? Comments?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MONA raises her hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, your name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He, I'm Mona.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, Mona.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I perfectly understand where you're coming from.  As a minority I can relate to your struggle also.  But I think you should give us all a chance.  We want this pilot to be successful just as much as you. Please don't be so quick to judge us based only on our whiteness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, is that what I'm doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BETH jumps in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think because of our background we can bring a unique perspective to Mantan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SETH pipes in also.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A fresh pair of eyes.  A new look, insight, new angle that hasn't been seen before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've heard this somewhere before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David raises his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My name is David.  I do think it would be better to have some African-American writers but for whatever reason they are not here. I don't know if they couldn't find any people with experience, they wouldn't work for the pay or refused to work for the show.  I don't know and nobody in this room probably knows either.  I'm looking at this as a unique opportunity. We all should.  I'm a damn good writer and I'm ready to go to work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone in the room applauds.  Sloan looks at Delacroix.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This thing was rigged, the deck was stacked, the fix was in.  Could Don King be near?  Good thing Sloan had my back.  She's my rock.  This was going to be a whole lot of work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David, I appreciate your comments. Anybody got an ideas?  Everybody just talk out loud.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've always liked the format of Rowan and Martin's "LAUGH-IN."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That could be cool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about something like "The Jeffersons?"  I grew up in Idaho so that's how I got my understanding of black people.  Through Sherman Helmsley, LOUISSEE!!!.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Good Times" was better.  Kid Dy-no mite!!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You pole are going to far back for me.  I think we have to go after a hipper feel.  Like the stuff Eddie Murphy used to do on "Saturday Night Live."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or Martin.  You go girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about the  black exploitation films?  No one has ever tried making that work on TV.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And for reason.  Have you ever seen "Scream Blacula, Scream?"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think, and Delacroix will agree with me, the politics of this show have to be right.  We should always be laughing with our characters, not at them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Delacroix, as the writers continue to ramble on, he lets them jerk off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The mission was accomplished.  All of these people left the room thinking they would have real input. I was writing this pilot alone, myself, me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A long line reaches down the block and around the corner. It's a "cattle call," open auditions for "Mantan."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now came the fun part, finding the talented performers to cast in the show.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WE DOLLY past the hundreds and hundreds of unemployed African American actors, many of them dressed in various costumes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everybody and their mother was trying to get in, trying to be seen. Trying to get their piece of the rock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Delacroix sits in the first row with Sloan, RUTH, an Afri American casting director.  LEVI, the musical director, a black, is on the stage at the piano.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WE SEE singers, magicians, dancers, acrobats, comedians, rappers.  Some good, most are terrible.  Many come out on stage dressed like mammies, Stepin' Fetchit, slaves, pimp ho's, hustlers, and basketball players.  It is a cavalcad of all the stereotypical roles one has seen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Space.  LULU, a spoken word artist, goes her rendition of

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This was amazing.  Who had told these Negroes that this was what we were looking for?  The same old image, it damn for sure wasn't me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lulu.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Were people this desperate to get work?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Delacroix.  He interrupts Lulu.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks, Ms. Lulu.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I had several more poems.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's good.  We've seen enough. We'll get back to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lulu scurries off stage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Next.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Mau-Mau's run onto the stage, yelling and screaming. They are all fired up, in fact several fire their 9mm's i the ceiling.

dialogues.speaker: TWO SHOT
dialogues.text: Delacroix and Sloan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is the group I was telling you about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which one is your brother?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The big one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ruth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's get started here.

dialogues.speaker: STAGE
dialogues.text: Big Black preens around on the stage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Mau-Mau's are up in dis place. That's right, the Mau-Mau's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's your name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My righteous name is BIG BLACK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what are the Mau-Mau's going to do for us today?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We gonna drop some knowledge, wisdom and understanding.  The Mau- Mau's, we be scientists.  We drop science.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sloan, who's trying to disappear.  If she sits any lower she'll be under her seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're ready when you are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Microphone check.  One.  Two.  One. Two.  One.  Two.  Hold up.  I gots to give my peeps some props. Brothers introduce yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yo, I'm Double Black.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Check it, Black Black.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm Smooth Black, the lover in dis' piece.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hard Black.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's Jo Black.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And he's Mo Black.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm last but not least, you can call me 1/16th Black.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good.  We're really blacked-oops, backed up, so shall we begin?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Microphone check.  One.  Two.  One. Two.  Yo, the name of this joint is BLAK IZ BLAK.  Hit it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The booming track starts and the Mau-Mau's do their thing bouncing all over the stage.  The lyrics about everything that is BLAK!!!

dialogues.speaker: ON DELACROIX
dialogues.text: A look of disbelief is on his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Needless to say, the Mau-Mau's did not fit into our plans.

dialogues.speaker: ON SLOAN
dialogues.text: She's in shock, horrified.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As I told Sloan, there's a black sheep in every family.

dialogues.speaker: BACKSTAGE
dialogues.text: Delacroix is screaming at the top of his lungs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Finland.  This is a travesty.  A debacle.  A mockery.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dunwitty approaches Delacroix in the lobby of the rehears space.  He is with JUKKA, a young, very young blonde kid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Delacroix.  This is the director I was telling you about.  Jukka Laks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So nice to meet you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice to meet you.  If you don't mind me asking you - how old are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just turned twenty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm gonna leave you two creative geniuses alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dunwitty, don't leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dunwitty is out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are you from?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Helsinki, which is the capital of Finland.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Finland.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, Finlandia vodka?  Yes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I know.  Jukka, have you ever seen a Negro person before?  Even had a real conversation with a real Negro before?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's a Negro.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Delacroix continues to rant and rave.  Sloan is unsuccess in attempting to make him be quiet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A fiasco.  A disaster.  A boondoggle. An abomination.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you just ask me what's a Negro? I'M A NEGRO!!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ahhh!!!  I never heard of that term before.  I thought you were BLACK of African-American.  No?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well before there was BLACK or AFRICAN AMERICAN, there were NEGROES.  I'M A NEGRO.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you for correcting my ignorance.  I'm looking forward to working side by side with you.  I feel we make a good team.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How did you get this gig?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My visual style is very erotic, sexy, how do you say - hot?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is a TV show, not a music video.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then will you teach me what I need to know.  Maybe we learn from each other, if that's possible, no?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is a travesty.  A debacle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've said that already.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm gonna slit my wrists.  Cut my throat.  For the love of Joseph.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's sitting behind his desk, reading new "pink" revision of the "MANTAN" pilot.  He screams.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For the love of Joseph and Mary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Delacroix bolts out from his office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Delacroix charges in as Dunwitty and Jukka go over the sa "pink" revisions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will not be held responsible for these revisions.  These changes are not the way I want to go.  This is an outrage.  This is a sham.  A violation!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Calm down, please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In Finland, when we get upset...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't give a good goddamn about Finland, Norway, Sweden or wherever ya blond ass came from.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We just punched it up a bit.  Made it funnier.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Funnier to who and at who's expense? Dunwitty, when Negroes start to run amok, the boycotts, when the demostrations commence, I'm giving them your home address.  Let's see how you like it when they picket your lawn in Greenwich, Connecticut.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I seriously doubt that will ever happen.  Didn't I tell you I know your people better than you do. But if by some miracle you're correct, I'm gonna invite them inside my house and we'll have a sit down, discuss it like civil human beings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Much activity is going on.  People are moving to and fro. WE FOLLOW Delacroix and Sloan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Delacroix knocks and they enter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mantan sits in front of his mirror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just want to say good luck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Break a leg.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She gives Mantan a kiss on his cheek.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait a minute.  Hold up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They all laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I kiss you too?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Naw.  I'll take the zero.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You feel good, not nervous?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I feel fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not nervous?  Relaxed?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sloan, will you take your boss out of here so I can get ready.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sloan and Delacroix enter the dressing room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's the audience?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fired up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How you feelin'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good.  I'm not sure about this material.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The material is fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sloan cuts a look at this liar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You really think so?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're trying to do something new here, some groundbreaking stuff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the bone breaking stuff I'm worried about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everything's gonna be alright.  You and Mantan will be huge stars after tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You really think so?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your life will never be the same.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
